Title: Remove TCG from game name!
Content:
Iâ€™m a level 50 player with a majority of cards collected. I was very excited to hear about trading where I could finish my collection instead of having to shell out 100s of dollars to try and hunt down a specific card. Turns out the system is so terrible that you can only trade basic EX and you need to sacrifice 4 cards for it?

There is no way this is a trading card game, more like an out to get your money game. Trying to blame bots or alt accounts for to justify this system being a â€œsmall indie companyâ€ is just a way to ensure people spend more money on the game. Change game name to PokÃ©mon OTGYM. 

I have over 100 dupes for some basic cards. What am I supposed to do with them? Canâ€™t use those for trade tokens of course. Maybe I can make unlimited decks with all those cards? Oh wait - 15 is the deck limit.
Combined:

I was very excited to hear about trading where I could finish my collection instead of having to shell out 100s of dollars to try and hunt down a specific card. Turns out the system is so terrible that you can only trade basic EX and you need to sacrifice 4 cards for it?

There is no way this is a trading card game, more like an out to get your money game. Trying to blame bots or alt accounts for to justify this system being a â€œsmall indie companyâ€ is just a way to ensure people spend more money on the game. Change game name to PokÃ©mon OTGYM. 

I have over 100 dupes for some basic cards. What am I supposed to do with them? Canâ€™t use those for trade tokens of course. Maybe I can make unlimited decks with all those cards? Oh wait - 15 is the deck limit.

Title: PvP issues!
Content:
Quite honestly the PVP has become completely broken with the latest update, adding darkrai into the field. 
The game was already completely luck based with about 1% skill involved. Now itâ€™s gotten 1000% worst than before. 

If they follow their trend they will eventually add YET ANOTHER win streak event. Which completely unrealistic for the casual player base. I have unlocked every medal and have spent plenty already into the game and yet I canâ€™t stand the pvp. From the coin flips, to the rng factor of starting hands compared to your opponent, and to the added factor of top decking exactly what you need for the situation or your opponent doing just that to squeeze out a victory. 

At the end of the day the medals and achievements are more of a sign of how lucky you can get, rather than a testament to your strategic mindset in the card battling field. Which is quite honestly sad. 

Fix suggestions: if they implemented a banning system for their event pvp modes to balance the field it would make it a lot more enjoyable. You could keep the open random pvp event for a â€œfree-for-allâ€ mode where every card can be used. 

However as it stands pvp is basically worthless and more of a question, whoâ€™s luckier? You? Or your opponent?
Combined:

Title: PVP is almost entirely luck based
Content:
Love the card collecting element and the nostalgia. Hate that winning any PvP match is almost entirely up to luck. Rarely will I ever see a situation where I win 9/10 due to good luck but seeing a situation where I lose 19/20 due to bad luck is common.

PVP also depends on building one of the cookie cutter decks  and then also good enough luck.
Combined:

PVP also depends on building one of the cookie cutter decks  and then also good enough luck.

Title: Money hungry RNG
Content:
First off why are you hiding the original three packs? Iâ€™m not finished the sets and since the new ones came out theyâ€™re not simply on the front page. Theyâ€™re hidden behind four pages.

Anyway, my first issue is with the UI, itâ€™s 2025â€¦ we know what looks and feels good to use. They donâ€™t care, itâ€™s pages and sub pages for no reason. For a game with almost no features why are there 30+ pages??? Itâ€™s so bloated to distract you from the lack of content. 

They released the trading system. You can only trade with friends, and canâ€™t trade more than a 1/3 of the cards in the game. And more than half will take all your trading energy/currency.

Of course this game has 12+ forms of currency!!!

Shop tickets, special black tickets, hour glasses, golden hour glasses, gold bars, event energy, trading energy, stardust, premium tickets(paid system) and letâ€™s not forget the three emblem currencies.

After opening 250 charizard packs Iâ€™m still missing 8 cards from the set. Like why.

On top of this, theyâ€™re keeping cards behind a paywall. Every month they have a special card (you use a 12th currency for) that only pass holders can obtain. 

I thought pay to win/ pay for advantages was illegal and thatâ€™s why cosmetics are being sold so much. Keeping cards behind a paywall also makes it so you canâ€™t even finish sets unless you pay for the pass.

Title: Give it a try!
Content:
Pros:
Itâ€™s PokÃ©mon! The art is really well done. Battle system is simple to learn. Auto battle feature makes it even easier. Deck building is easy and intuitive. The PokÃ©mon themselves are cute, cool and fun to collect. They keep introducing new cards and variations on old ones which keeps the game fresh.
Cons:
Battle system is a bit too simple once you understand it. Going second is an advantage that doesnâ€™t exist in the original card game. The energy supply system is better in the original card game and more fair. Needs a power balance as Charizard EX is simply too OP, capable of dealing over 200 damage which is more than any PokÃ©mon has. Moltres EX can add 1-4 energy every turn meaning you could have Charizard at full charge in 3-4 moves (counting evolutions). Itâ€™s really just poor balancing. I think power creep could be an issue. If you keep increasing power to match charizard, you risk power creep and then anything under 200 hp that deals less than 200 damage will no longer be viable. If you work out a battle system closer to the original card game where there are energy cards and both players have equal opportunity to add them, it could help balance a bit without the power creep being a factor. 
Final take: play the game! Donâ€™t take it too seriously and just have fun and collect PokÃ©mon. Itâ€™s great for what it is and Iâ€™m confident it will continue to be interesting with added card sets and new solo challenges. If you want the nostalgia, youâ€™ll get the nostalgia. If you are new to PokÃ©mon, this is a really fun way to start.
Combined:

Cons:

The energy supply system is better in the original card game and more fair. Needs a power balance as Charizard EX is simply too OP, capable of dealing over 200 damage which is more than any PokÃ©mon has. Moltres EX can add 1-4 energy every turn meaning you could have Charizard at full charge in 3-4 moves (counting evolutions). Itâ€™s really just poor balancing. I think power creep could be an issue. If you keep increasing power to match charizard, you risk power creep and then anything under 200 hp that deals less than 200 damage will no longer be viable. If you work out a battle system closer to the original card game where there are energy cards and both players have equal opportunity to add them, it could help balance a bit without the power creep being a factor. 
Final take: play the game! Donâ€™t take it too seriously and just have fun and collect PokÃ©mon. Itâ€™s great for what it is and Iâ€™m confident it will continue to be interesting with added card sets and new solo challenges. If you want the nostalgia, youâ€™ll get the nostalgia. Title: Trading
Content: First off I started playing a few months ago and I loved the game, so when I heard there was going to be trading I was ecstatic. I had already bought the Nintendo pokemon violet and Pokemon sword games and loved both, but more importantly I bought Nintendo switch online for the trade feature that they had which was 100% worth it. So in my opinion to make the trade feature better in TCGP, just copy exactly what Pokemon violet did so that there is more freedom to trade. I tried trading a charizard ex for a regular rare with my friend but it didnâ€™t let me because of the rarity difference. I needed that card to finish my collection, so I just think you need to allow any  rarity to be tradable  for any rarity. Also I think there shouldnâ€™t be a trade limit but one problem at a time.
Combined: TradingFirst off I started playing a few months ago and I loved the game, so when I heard there was going to be trading I was ecstatic. I had already bought the Nintendo pokemon violet and Pokemon sword games and loved both, but more importantly I bought Nintendo switch online for the trade feature that they had which was 100% worth it. So in my opinion to make the trade feature better in TCGP, just copy exactly what Pokemon violet did so that there is more freedom to trade. I tried trading a charizard ex for a regular rare with my friend but it didnâ€™t let me because of the rarity difference. I needed that card to finish my collection, so I just think you need to allow any  rarity to be tradable  for any rarity. Also I think there shouldnâ€™t be a trade limit but one problem at a time.

Title: Trading suggestion
Content:
I have been enjoying the game quite a bit. The only real change I would make to this game is in regards to trading.It would be helpful to be able to see my friendsâ€™ wishlists when trading and vice versa. 

It would streamline the process of trading if I could offer a card my friend actually wants. 

I donâ€™t know in person any of the friends in my friend list so I canâ€™t communicate what Iâ€™m looking for outside the game. Maybe an incentive to trade my friend a card they have wishlisted would be to earn some of the in game rewards like the hourglasses or tickets or at least trade stamina. 

As it stands I donâ€™t trade that often.

Iâ€™d also like to have wonder trades be an option just like in the video game. Itâ€™s fun to get a surprise.

Title: getting greedy
Content:
Hoping the devs read this and change course. this game was really fun to make part of my daily routine ... until recent updates where they are taking the fun away and replacing it with places i can spend money.

before, i could save up my time capsules and open 10 packs in one shot if i saved up for weeks. then in a new update, i suddenly can't do that anymore, i have to pay gold. keep in mind, you still had to pay for the time capsules if you didn't want to wait two weeks of daily logins and quests. so, you just cut off the people who were actually engaging with the app and enjoying it ... in hopes that what? i'd pay money?

and the event drop rates are now ruthless. before i played through the gyarados event, it was super fun, played challenges, earned like 4 of them ... not this time. i beat all 5 challenges and one of them twice, didn't earn a single cresslia. 

guys, relax, you're making money. maybe think about keeping the fun. i i've pokemon but i don't need to login week after week to see updates with greedy tweaks to take a way the fun.
Combined:
getting greedyHoping the devs read this and change course. this game was really fun to make part of my daily routine ... until recent updates where they are taking the fun away and replacing it with places i can spend money.

before, i could save up my time capsules and open 10 packs in one shot if i saved up for weeks. then in a new update, i suddenly can't do that anymore, i have to pay gold. keep in mind, you still had to pay for the time capsules if you didn't want to wait two weeks of daily logins and quests. so, you just cut off the people who were actually engaging with the app and enjoying it ... in hopes that what? i'd pay money?

and the event drop rates are now ruthless. before i played through the gyarados event, it was super fun, played challenges, earned like 4 of them ... not this time. i beat all 5 challenges and one of them twice, didn't earn a single cresslia. 

guys, relax, you're making money. maybe think about keeping the fun. i i've pokemon but i don't need to login week after week to see updates with greedy tweaks to take a way the fun.

Title: Fantastic Game
Content:
I love this game. And as someone with a 9 to 5 job, I have finally been able to complete a deck (I wonâ€™t say which to keep this unbiased)

As of now, any deck can beat each other. I am begging the devs to keep the game balanced as new cards and packs are added. See what happened to Clash Royale to see what happens when the greed takes over (losing playerbase)

Not all players have the time or the money to keep up with all of the meta changes. All I ask is that my deck remains competitive regardless of what cards are added

Title: Greedy, UI too complex
Content:
To expand on the UI complaint, there's a submenu to do anything at all, and every button pressed initiates another wifi loaded menu. Every submenu takes up to a second to open, just to select more subcommands to do more subcommands, opening your deck to look for a pokemon is like 5-6 buttons and menus to get through.

Additionally, they're really stingy with the rewards, you're lucky to pull three or 4 packs of 5 cards daily if you really try, that's 10 cards per day of 5 cards each out of hundreds added at varying rarities. The PvE is rewarding but limited and repetitive. Overall I think this is a cash grab, overengineered UI app trying to get you to spend $10 as fast as possible so you can be disappointed with its unsatisfying rewards.
Combined:
Greedy, UI too complexTo expand on the UI complaint, there's a submenu to do anything at all, and every button pressed initiates another wifi loaded menu. Every submenu takes up to a second to open, just to select more subcommands to do more subcommands, opening your deck to look for a pokemon is like 5-6 buttons and menus to get through.

Additionally, they're really stingy with the rewards, you're lucky to pull three or 4 packs of 5 cards daily if you really try, that's 10 cards per day of 5 cards each out of hundreds added at varying rarities. The PvE is rewarding but limited and repetitive. Overall I think this is a cash grab, overengineered UI app trying to get you to spend $10 as fast as possible so you can be disappointed with its unsatisfying rewards.

Out of nowhere the game queued up the next energy and instead of being a metal energy like all the rest of the matches Ive had recently. It queued up an ELECTRIC energy, causing me to forfeit the match? Why did this happen? Why did I get an electric energy when I donâ€™t even have that selected, heres my setup. Please explain or go to my last match and check if the other player cheated to give me that electric energy cause this doesnâ€™t make any sense.

Title: Great game
Content: Add more difficulty settings for the verses games. Thereâ€™s two options: beginner and trading card player.  Say Iâ€™m a beginner at level 17 Iâ€™m not even sure if thatâ€™s beginner but when I go in with a new deck and I have no clue how to play it then a level 36 shows up and defeats me before I even got a chance to add energy to my cards then at the next battle, same thing. And vice versa i had went against a level 9,then a 10 and I felt bad because my deck was stronger because I had the chance to acquire more cards than they had. Great game though ! fun to play during lunch breaks. with the solo battles Iâ€™ve gone through most of them already. But I got into the verses and I can say wow need some upgrades. Each difficulty should go like : beginners, intermediate, hard, and expert, then to advanced. Sorta like the solo battles are rated as. So a level 36 can play in intermediate while me at 17 can play beginner with my lousy decks. just add more difficultyâ€™s with the versus so that when I want to play against people at my level I can or have the option to play my hand at higher level players when I feel comfortable.

Title: Idk

Title: Algorithm
Content:
This game has too many rigged algorithms. It honestly reminds me of Marvel Snap. Marvel Snap became a huge failure. Pocket has algorithms youâ€™ll start to notice. Like using a deck and losing to Celebii 5 times in a row. Then switching your deck to beat Celebii, now only to fight Misty decks 5 times in a row. Also going first is a huge disadvantage. Iâ€™ve gone first 10+ times in a row. Thatâ€™s not â€œrandomâ€.

Right now everything is based around Drudigon stalling the game, which means certain decks have no chance attacking, cause the Pokemon will just KO itself. The other way is energy manipulation. Misty, Serperior, Moltres, and Gardevoir. If youâ€™re not using a deck involving those cards then games are a lot slower for you.

Thereâ€™s also 4 cards that basically go into every deck. 2 Pokeballs, and 2 Professor Oaks. So itâ€™s more a deck of 16 cards, not 20. Thereâ€™s a bunch of filler cards that youâ€™ll never see used. Every card should be designed with a potential use over another card, giving you options. Some cards here are just pure garbage to put in packs.

After playing for 3-4 months this is my honest opinion of the state of the game. It has become very stale and boring.
Combined:

Like using a deck and losing to Celebii 5 times in a row. Then switching your deck to beat Celebii, now only to fight Misty decks 5 times in a row. Also going first is a huge disadvantage. Right now everything is based around Drudigon stalling the game, which means certain decks have no chance attacking, cause the Pokemon will just KO itself. The other way is energy manipulation. Misty, Serperior, Moltres, and Gardevoir. If youâ€™re not using a deck involving those cards then games are a lot slower for you.

Thereâ€™s also 4 cards that basically go into every deck. 2 Pokeballs, and 2 Professor Oaks. So itâ€™s more a deck of 16 cards, not 20. Thereâ€™s a bunch of filler cards that youâ€™ll never see used. Every card should be designed with a potential use over another card, giving you options. Some cards here are just pure garbage to put in packs.

After playing for 3-4 months this is my honest opinion of the state of the game. It has become very stale and boring.

Title: BATTLES ARE HORRIBLE
Content: Upon downloading this game you are met with amazing card pulls to keep ur attention and its highly addictive if any other pokemon game would be. However what makes this a GAME (TCG) is the battling option where after completing virtually all easily available challenges is the ONLY WAY TO LEVEL UP. I want to grind battles and get better but EVERY SINGLE MATCH I go against level 30 plus players with ever meta EX spam 200+ damage deck when IM ONLY LEVEL 8!!! How hard is it to add a feature when you go against people around the same level as you to even the odds?!? Surely the player base is big enough!?!? No reason me and everyone I know or read about is getting spammed by Celebi EX and Coffing, this has made the game so frustrating and unplayable seeing as 1 in every 10 matches I play I go against someone the same level as me with a normal deck. FIX THIS ISSUE!!!!!
Combined: BATTLES ARE HORRIBLEUpon downloading this game you are met with amazing card pulls to keep ur attention and its highly addictive if any other pokemon game would be. However what makes this a GAME (TCG) is the battling option where after completing virtually all easily available challenges is the ONLY WAY TO LEVEL UP. I want to grind battles and get better but EVERY SINGLE MATCH I go against level 30 plus players with ever meta EX spam 200+ damage deck when IM ONLY LEVEL 8!!! How hard is it to add a feature when you go against people around the same level as you to even the odds?!? Surely the player base is big enough!?!? No reason me and everyone I know or read about is getting spammed by Celebi EX and Coffing, this has made the game so frustrating and unplayable seeing as 1 in every 10 matches I play I go against someone the same level as me with a normal deck. FIX THIS ISSUE!!!!!

Title: CPU Battles need serious balancing
Content:
CPU battles need a ridiculous amount of balancing. Iâ€™ve maybe had a handful of matches that were challenging without cheapness and were won by strategy, as it should be. 

But typically, CPU battles go one of two ways. The most annoying and, for me, prevalent is the CPU gets every possible advantage starting with the coin toss, fills out their bench with PokÃ©mon and fully evolves at least half of their PokÃ©mon while Iâ€™m stuck with a handful of third stage evolves only drawing the second stage when the battle is a turn from done. Things work out so perfectly it seems like there is zero chance in their card draws, pulling exactly what they need at that given time. And if your deck or their deck has cards dependent on a coin toss, forget it. They get a card like Misty and get heads all the way through. I can count on one hand the number of times a coin flip for my cards went in my favor. You meticulously create a deck for yourself trying to avoid coin toss cards and too many evolves, but even then if the CPU still gains every advantage, why bother?

Sometimes, mainly noticed on the easier battles, you get a clean sweep because the CPU avoids obvious moves, like trading out a nearly defeated PokÃ©mon. 

It feels like CPU battles are an afterthought because instead of making it organically challenging and realistic, you either get decimated with no hope of strategy or deck building helping you to succeed or sometimes you get matches where the CPU still gains every advantage and just awkwardly seems to shuffle things around waiting for you to defeat their max evolved PokÃ©mon. 

Coin flips should at least give some sort of illusion of there being a 50-50 chance but itâ€™s more like 1-99. Iâ€™m no mathematical statistics expert, but that kind of seems a bit broken to me.
Combined:

Coin flips should at least give some sort of illusion of there being a 50-50 chance but itâ€™s more like 1-99. Iâ€™m no mathematical statistics expert, but that kind of seems a bit broken to me.

Title: Amazing game, needs trading changes
Content:
Dear PokÃ©mon, 

This game is amazing. I love the original card illustrations and animations. They really spice up the card game.

On the other hand, trading needs some work. I think I have a solution. Add 2FA to PokÃ©mon if you want to trade higher rarity cards. Then, if you are wanting to trade, make it a live thing where you put down the cards you want to trade and include buttons that say add more, confirm, and less.

Amazing game, needs trading changesDear PokÃ©mon, 

This game is amazing. I love the original card illustrations and animations. They really spice up the card game.

On the other hand, trading needs some work. I think I have a solution. Add 2FA to PokÃ©mon if you want to trade higher rarity cards. Then, if you are wanting to trade, make it a live thing where you put down the cards you want to trade and include buttons that say add more, confirm, and less.

Title: Don't expect to play for free
Content:
It is a "free to play" game, but you get nowhere close to complete collection or being able to build a top ranking deck as getting one specific card can be extremely expensive more than you think. Even premium pass and some small purchases gets you nowhere. Expect to spend hundreds of dollars to simply catch up.

99% pay to win. Remaining 1% is pure luck.

Title: Good free to play TCG
Content:
Good high quality game. Dont have to spend any money to get a lot of cards. Never encountered a bug.

RECOMMENDATIONS: wonder trade of equal value cards, allow trading of current set cards, and allow flairing cards even if you only have one or two of them. Needing 3 seems like a very arbitrary restriction.

Title: â€¦like PokÃ©mon? Try for free, maybe not PvP.
Content: The PokÃ©mon theme is the main attraction. For a freemium pay-to-win, advertisements are minimal. If you donâ€™t like the idea of gaining unique rewards though competing with pay-to-win players or spending out-of-game money, you may enjoy the solo content or playing with friends. :::: If a random Opponent appears to be doing nothing, you may need to frequently refresh your application to avoid a loss from connection issues. :::: SPOILERS :::: (these may seem obvious, but there are similar games which have none of them) :::: Bad strategies can be a definitive loss. A player can win before their Opponent is able to take a turn. Pay-to-win and high-luck strategies can create a lack of diversity, interest, and skill. Players can stall, potentially taking more than 10 times the necessary Turn time. Equally-matched players result in coin-flip wins or ties. In game, Players canâ€™t compare cards with Friends for Trade.

Title: Trading mechanics are trash.
Content: Pokemon talks a big game about having a focus on community, and they often point to trading being their proudest example of that. But for some reason, theyâ€™ve decided that the TRADING card game app should be near impossible to trade on. You have to have a stupid amount of trade tokens to trade most cards, which you only get by trashing very high rarity cards, or by grabbing the occasional pity gifts. On top of that, cards above 1 star rarity canâ€™t be traded at all. Essentially, for people trying to complete their collections, extra promo, 2 star, 3 star and crown rarity cards have absolutely no value or purpose. They are just very pretty trash. Pokemon, if you care about community, you need to remember accessibility matters. If you gatekeep trading, you are denying access to an essential and fun feature of the game at its core to your player base. Please look elsewhere for a money grab and let us enjoy something that should be adorable and fun.
Combined: Trading mechanics are trash.Pokemon talks a big game about having a focus on community, and they often point to trading being their proudest example of that. But for some reason, theyâ€™ve decided that the TRADING card game app should be near impossible to trade on. You have to have a stupid amount of trade tokens to trade most cards, which you only get by trashing very high rarity cards, or by grabbing the occasional pity gifts. On top of that, cards above 1 star rarity canâ€™t be traded at all. Essentially, for people trying to complete their collections, extra promo, 2 star, 3 star and crown rarity cards have absolutely no value or purpose. They are just very pretty trash. Pokemon, if you care about community, you need to remember accessibility matters. If you gatekeep trading, you are denying access to an essential and fun feature of the game at its core to your player base. Please look elsewhere for a money grab and let us enjoy something that should be adorable and fun.

Title: Attention duelists
Content:
First and foremost, there is no trading in PokÃ©mon Trading Card Game Pocket yet. Iâ€™m guessing when it does get added, it will disappoint a lot of people based on how limited the F2P model is. 

Edit: Guess I was right!

This game does a good job of sucking you in at first, but it slows down quickly. 

To be clear, you can slowly build up a collection over time and get most of the cards you want. Your overall luck opening/picking cards will determine what you can battle with while building up your collection, but that luck can vary wildly. 

The game is light on content and has already resorted to repeating its first few ideas. 
It makes me wonder if this game was pushed out early to cover for delays elsewhere in the franchise. They have tons of media they could reference for ideas and theyâ€™ve chosen to do only the most basic stuff. 

Battles are a large part of the experience if you arenâ€™t spending money to open packs. The 20 card 2 copy limit offers its own pros and cons. Because of how limited the card pool is, the competitive aspect of the game is limited as well. Most battles are won based on playing two cards. Theyâ€™re the only two cards that draw more cards, and if one person plays more of them, theyâ€™re probably going to win. Luck matters in all card games, but you can really feel it in this one. The game is up front about being casual though, so maybe the high variance is how they hope to achieve that. 

Evolutions require a unique card for each stage. Getting a basic, middle, and final evolution into play in sequence is tough with the limited card pool. Basically, high variance is (almost) everywhere. This will likely get better as more trainer cards and PokÃ©mon with abilities come out. 

Even though battling others in PVP is the majority of the content right now, only the winning player gets a reward of 15 exp (not a lot), meaning if you start losing a game or just get a bad opener itâ€™s reasonable to just concede and try again. There is no penalty for losses. This cheapens the overall experience for both sides. I donâ€™t think they should add a penalty, but both players should be rewarded for completing a battle.

The F2P economy is a bit stingy. Two packs a day is great as a baseline, but the game doesnâ€™t reward you much for actually playing. Daily missions give you additional pack every 3-4 days. If you level up you get a free pack. Packs contain five cards. 

Rarity also isnâ€™t intuitive. Three diamond cards are more rare than most EX cards because EX cards often have alternate arts. This means you have more chances to see Pickachu EX than a Magneton because there are technically three different Pickachu EX cards that could end up in your pack.

Pack Points are the biggest issue for me and why I rate the game so poorly. I would be able to ignore the aggressiveness of the monetization if I was able to craft a few important low-rarity cards I canâ€™t seem to open. 

I would love a way to convert duplicate cards into cards that I need. Five cards per pack with no guaranteed rares (three diamond of above) means youâ€™ll have gaps in your collection unless you have exceptional luck. The majority of packs you open will just be one and two diamond cards.

I was missing a two diamond card despite opening 40+ of the pack it was in. This means I needed to spend a week of pack points to get one uncommon. Each pack opened gives 5 points and two diamond cards cost 70 points, meaning all your free packs for about a week (2/day is 10 pack points a day). I happened to open my third copy a day later, not a great experience as a F2P. I was saving my pack points to get an EX card for my starving family. 

Hereâ€™s an example of just how stingy they are with rewards. They gave away a few free packs as part of their holiday event. These packs did not give pack points when opened. They wonâ€™t even let players get 15~ free pack points for a yearly holiday event. 

Trading could also fix this, but it isnâ€™t in PokÃ©mon Trading Card Game Pocket yet. Iâ€™m guessing trading will be very restricted because they stand to lose way too much money if people can complete their collection through trading. My guess is that each account will get some number of free trades and the rest will cost PokÃ©gold. I just donâ€™t see them letting people trade without â€˜taking their cutâ€™. 

Wonder picks are the other side of the economy and it is just engineered FOMO at its worst. Showing you that you â€˜pickedâ€™ incorrectly on failed attempts is definitely a choice when there are videos showing RNG is decided on packs and picks the instant resources are spent. You can and will get lucky, but the pool of cards is already large enough that finding even the right booster pack is a challenge. This is likely meant to be a catch-up mechanic for newer players and an occasional bonus for others. 

The UI needs work as well, itâ€™s very barebones and not well organized. There are a lot of screens involved in obtaining cards that I wish were skippable. For another example, the best way to give your friends thanks is to go to the community display and scroll to the bottom. Going into the friends list to do the same thing requires 3 taps and some loading for each account manually. Deck building UI/search is also very poorly set up. 

Overall, itâ€™s the most polished version of PokÃ©mon Shop Iâ€™ve played, but they really need to fix the reward structure. I think the game has potential, but right now it feels like itâ€™s an undercooked cash cow first and a game second.
Combined:
Attention duelistsFirst and foremost, there is no trading in PokÃ©mon Trading Card Game Pocket yet. Iâ€™m guessing when it does get added, it will disappoint a lot of people based on how limited the F2P model is. 

Edit: Guess I was right!

This game does a good job of sucking you in at first, but it slows down quickly. 

To be clear, you can slowly build up a collection over time and get most of the cards you want. Your overall luck opening/picking cards will determine what you can battle with while building up your collection, but that luck can vary wildly. 

The game is light on content and has already resorted to repeating its first few ideas. 
It makes me wonder if this game was pushed out early to cover for delays elsewhere in the franchise. They have tons of media they could reference for ideas and theyâ€™ve chosen to do only the most basic stuff. 

Battles are a large part of the experience if you arenâ€™t spending money to open packs. The 20 card 2 copy limit offers its own pros and cons. Because of how limited the card pool is, the competitive aspect of the game is limited as well. Most battles are won based on playing two cards. Theyâ€™re the only two cards that draw more cards, and if one person plays more of them, theyâ€™re probably going to win. Luck matters in all card games, but you can really feel it in this one. The game is up front about being casual though, so maybe the high variance is how they hope to achieve that. 

Evolutions require a unique card for each stage. Getting a basic, middle, and final evolution into play in sequence is tough with the limited card pool. Basically, high variance is (almost) everywhere. This will likely get better as more trainer cards and PokÃ©mon with abilities come out. 

Even though battling others in PVP is the majority of the content right now, only the winning player gets a reward of 15 exp (not a lot), meaning if you start losing a game or just get a bad opener itâ€™s reasonable to just concede and try again. There is no penalty for losses. This cheapens the overall experience for both sides. I donâ€™t think they should add a penalty, but both players should be rewarded for completing a battle.

The F2P economy is a bit stingy. Two packs a day is great as a baseline, but the game doesnâ€™t reward you much for actually playing. Daily missions give you additional pack every 3-4 days. If you level up you get a free pack. Packs contain five cards. 

Rarity also isnâ€™t intuitive. Three diamond cards are more rare than most EX cards because EX cards often have alternate arts. This means you have more chances to see Pickachu EX than a Magneton because there are technically three different Pickachu EX cards that could end up in your pack.

Pack Points are the biggest issue for me and why I rate the game so poorly. I would be able to ignore the aggressiveness of the monetization if I was able to craft a few important low-rarity cards I canâ€™t seem to open. 

I would love a way to convert duplicate cards into cards that I need. Five cards per pack with no guaranteed rares (three diamond of above) means youâ€™ll have gaps in your collection unless you have exceptional luck. The majority of packs you open will just be one and two diamond cards.

I was missing a two diamond card despite opening 40+ of the pack it was in. This means I needed to spend a week of pack points to get one uncommon. Each pack opened gives 5 points and two diamond cards cost 70 points, meaning all your free packs for about a week (2/day is 10 pack points a day). I happened to open my third copy a day later, not a great experience as a F2P. I was saving my pack points to get an EX card for my starving family. 

Hereâ€™s an example of just how stingy they are with rewards. They gave away a few free packs as part of their holiday event. These packs did not give pack points when opened. They wonâ€™t even let players get 15~ free pack points for a yearly holiday event. 

Trading could also fix this, but it isnâ€™t in PokÃ©mon Trading Card Game Pocket yet. Iâ€™m guessing trading will be very restricted because they stand to lose way too much money if people can complete their collection through trading. My guess is that each account will get some number of free trades and the rest will cost PokÃ©gold. I just donâ€™t see them letting people trade without â€˜taking their cutâ€™. 

Wonder picks are the other side of the economy and it is just engineered FOMO at its worst. Showing you that you â€˜pickedâ€™ incorrectly on failed attempts is definitely a choice when there are videos showing RNG is decided on packs and picks the instant resources are spent. You can and will get lucky, but the pool of cards is already large enough that finding even the right booster pack is a challenge. This is likely meant to be a catch-up mechanic for newer players and an occasional bonus for others. 

The UI needs work as well, itâ€™s very barebones and not well organized. There are a lot of screens involved in obtaining cards that I wish were skippable. For another example, the best way to give your friends thanks is to go to the community display and scroll to the bottom. Going into the friends list to do the same thing requires 3 taps and some loading for each account manually. Deck building UI/search is also very poorly set up. 

Overall, itâ€™s the most polished version of PokÃ©mon Shop Iâ€™ve played, but they really need to fix the reward structure. I think the game has potential, but right now it feels like itâ€™s an undercooked cash cow first and a game second.

Title: So Much More Can Be Done
Content:
I love PokÃ©mon and grew up with it which is why I can appreciate a game like this. With that said, this is the most basic attempt at a card game simulation Iâ€™ve seen.

Itâ€™s clear theyâ€™re completely banking on the nostalgia, and itâ€™s clearly working. Which is why itâ€™s likely they will not add any creative mechanics or attempt at fostering a game which incentivizes any form of strategic gameplay or even slight diversity of reward opportunities. 

The artwork is beautiful and I look forward to that aspect but putting in a grind for such boring rewards like an emblem or an hourglass here and there just becomes monotonous. Initially, I was playing this daily and looking forward to completing my sets of cards. But the novelty has worn off and every few days I may remember to open some free packs but thatâ€™s it. 

So much can be done with this game, and they certainly have the profits to do so, which is why itâ€™s so disappointing that they likely wonâ€™t.
Combined:
So Much More Can Be DoneI love PokÃ©mon and grew up with it which is why I can appreciate a game like this. With that said, this is the most basic attempt at a card game simulation Iâ€™ve seen.

Itâ€™s clear theyâ€™re completely banking on the nostalgia, and itâ€™s clearly working. Which is why itâ€™s likely they will not add any creative mechanics or attempt at fostering a game which incentivizes any form of strategic gameplay or even slight diversity of reward opportunities. 

The artwork is beautiful and I look forward to that aspect but putting in a grind for such boring rewards like an emblem or an hourglass here and there just becomes monotonous. Initially, I was playing this daily and looking forward to completing my sets of cards. But the novelty has worn off and every few days I may remember to open some free packs but thatâ€™s it. 

So much can be done with this game, and they certainly have the profits to do so, which is why itâ€™s so disappointing that they likely wonâ€™t.

Title: Not Bad, But Flawed
Content:
Iâ€™ve been playing since release and Iâ€™m a premium account player. I have like 3000 cards every promo and love the collecting portion of the game. 
On the other hand, the battling is garbage. Absolute garbage. I donâ€™t understand how Iâ€™m so consistently unlucky. On a 2 flip coin toss, never think at least one will be heads. Always double tails ALWAYS. Celebi with the 12 coin toss, 4 heads outta 12. 
Out of 20 cards in a deck how am I always drawing 2nd & 3rd forms and my basics are ALL on the bottom or vice-versa, my final forms will always be on the bottom. The game is sentient and refuses to ever give me an edge. I donâ€™t even do PvP battles anymore because something about the battling constantly feels rigged and I KNOW what Iâ€™m doing. I play Pokemon TCG all the time for like 25yrs. 
Going FIRST in a match is essentially â€œyouâ€™re going to loseâ€ having an edge on the first energy is absolutely essential to avoid getting wrecked, but the game really wants you to go first. Like it REALLY wants you to go first, because it KNOWS being second is advantageousâ€¦.sick. I hate this game more and more every week. 
Trading is hilarious, I thought it was going to be the real reason to play this game but nah. Trading was also just released and OF COURSE Pokemon company makes it super convoluted and requires currency and you have to earn the right to trade rarer cards. Pokemon company is run by greedy losers with no brains and Iâ€™m tired of being nickel and dimed from this company whoâ€™s consistently released mediocre content for over the last 10yrs.

Title: Hyped up trading just to disappoint
Content:
Review in hopes they fix trading:
Trading should be one for one without tokens, otherwise there should've been a warning when flairing 3-diamond cards just as when flairing 4-diamond and higher rarities. Letting your consumer base flair 11 3-diamond cards and then telling them that they needed those to trade is a slap in the face. Current trading is also akin to groping blindly in the dark and fairly pathetic. C'mon developers.

Title: If you're free to play, don't duel
Content:
My last review disappeared, minus 1 star. Kidding, kidding. 

It's fun for collecting cards, but the duel aspect is absolute garbage. So many of the cards involve coin flipping, and the coin flip is definitely not RNG (random number generator). It is absolutely not even and you will experience it yourself as you flip 10 coins to have 9 of them be tails, while the computer flips 5 heads in a row. In a row! Your patience will absolutely be tested and the game makes me close it every time I try to duel because of the unfairness. Haters will say it's copium. Maybe it is, maybe it's Maybelline

Content:

Every day, 4 Pack Hourglasses for completing 3-4 costly and time consuming tasks. One free Wonder Pick Hourglass of which you need a collective total of 36 hours/Hourglasses to get ONE shot at a decent card (1-2 Star) to then get shafted by the placement of a common, 1-Diamond card.

Donâ€™t even get me started on the premium rewards that take days (even with spending up to $100 on pack openings) to complete. Absolutely amazing how you developers think that, we who play every single day, are enjoying getting shafted just by opening the app.

The rates for pulls are divided by tens of thousands on the percentage. Most 10-pack openings and prices for gold to open them are strangely arranged so that you have just enough to make one more purchase and open another pack(s). 

Oh and heads on the coin-flips are made out to be 50/50? 
NINETY PERCENT OF THE PLAYERS CAN SEE THIS IS A LIE!!!

I, strongly, believe that your â€œOnline Battle Systemâ€ is actually â€œAI-generated battles, using player names and builds, while storing the algorithm to concede if the game doesnâ€™t flow smoothly for the opponentâ€. I donâ€™t even think any of this sounds Farfetchâ€™d.
Combined:

Every day, 4 Pack Hourglasses for completing 3-4 costly and time consuming tasks. One free Wonder Pick Hourglass of which you need a collective total of 36 hours/Hourglasses to get ONE shot at a decent card (1-2 Star) to then get shafted by the placement of a common, 1-Diamond card.

Donâ€™t even get me started on the premium rewards that take days (even with spending up to $100 on pack openings) to complete. Absolutely amazing how you developers think that, we who play every single day, are enjoying getting shafted just by opening the app.

The rates for pulls are divided by tens of thousands on the percentage. Most 10-pack openings and prices for gold to open them are strangely arranged so that you have just enough to make one more purchase and open another pack(s). 

Oh and heads on the coin-flips are made out to be 50/50? 
NINETY PERCENT OF THE PLAYERS CAN SEE THIS IS A LIE!!!

I, strongly, believe that your â€œOnline Battle Systemâ€ is actually â€œAI-generated battles, using player names and builds, while storing the algorithm to concede if the game doesnâ€™t flow smoothly for the opponentâ€. I donâ€™t even think any of this sounds Farfetchâ€™d.

Title: Good potential butâ€¦
Content: The premium pass isnâ€™t worth the price. After the first week or two the amount of progress you can make in this game without spending money drops to a very slow and frustrating pace. Itâ€™s a typical phone game meant to squeeze money out of whales and kids by using a popular brand to get attention. The game has the potential to be good but itâ€™s obvious the developers care more about making every possible penny from users over making a fun game that is worth putting time into, but thatâ€™s the case with most phone games so no one should be surprised. Sadge

Title: time until pack opening
Content:
i love this game! it's so fun and the want to collect all of the cards always keep me coming back. i love all of the little accessories and add-ons for my custom decks, as well as all of the little events. my only issue is that when i go to open a pack and i have to use my hourglasses to reduce the time. for example, if there is 1 hour and 15 minutes until i can open my next pack, i have to use two hourglasses. i would love it if you would only have to use one less hourglass in situations like that (if the time is _ hours, 30 mins). 

basically if the timer's minutes are less than half of an hour (30 mins or less), then i shouldn't have to use another hourglass as if i was reducing the time for another hour. 
i'm not sure if this makes sense or not, but i'm not sure how to explain it.

game currently:
3 hours, 29 mins = 4 hourglasses

my idea:
3 hours 29 mins = 3 hourglasses

i'm not sure if the way this is setup currently is done for a reason and my idea is stupid but it makes sense in my head lol
Combined:

basically if the timer's minutes are less than half of an hour (30 mins or less), then i shouldn't have to use another hourglass as if i was reducing the time for another hour. 
i'm not sure if this makes sense or not, but i'm not sure how to explain it.

game currently:

my idea:

i'm not sure if the way this is setup currently is done for a reason and my idea is stupid but it makes sense in my head lol

Title: The real card game is better
Content: This games shouldâ€™ve been called coin flip simulator because thatâ€™s what matches comes down to, or you just pay for the good cards and dominate. I know itâ€™s similar in irl tcg because you can still pay for good to make it easier to win, but the game mechanics are different enough to make the game feel like it all comes down to a coin flip. The prize cards and being able to place an energy on one mon per turn made it feel more fair, I havenâ€™t pulled any cards that let me put energies down freely and it just seems so unfair. Only reason I keep playing is because pulling good cards feels better than gambling and I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s inherently a good thing.

I know itâ€™s similar in irl tcg because you can still pay for good to make it easier to win, but the game mechanics are different enough to make the game feel like it all comes down to a coin flip. The prize cards and being able to place an energy on one mon per turn made it feel more fair, I havenâ€™t pulled any cards that let me put energies down freely and it just seems so unfair. Content: This is first and foremost not a trading card game. In no other TCG would you have to pay to trade or be limited to only being able to trade certain cards a day. I started playing it because Iâ€™m an avid collector of the physical cards, which I can trade or give away as I see fit. The lack of autonomy over oneâ€™s own collection in this game is 100% deserving of a one star review.

Title: The Players Ruin The Game
Content: This game is very fun and has a lot of great strategies. Sadly once you get to a certain level all the players use the same one. First it was Mewtwo/Gardevoir, or Charizard/Moltres, then it was Celibi/Serperior, now its Darkrai/Magnezone. I get that these are good decks, but when four out of every five battles is the same deck it makes the game feel very repetitive. Then there's the problem of opponents quitting the match whenever you take the lead. It is very rare for me to actually complete a match that I am winning because so many players ragequit. It cheapens the victory and doesn't let me enjoy winning. my experience is mostky people spamming the same deck and rage quitting if I start to win. That is not the games fault, but it would be nice to find some way to disincentivise this behavior someway.
Combined: The Players Ruin The GameThis game is very fun and has a lot of great strategies. Sadly once you get to a certain level all the players use the same one. First it was Mewtwo/Gardevoir, or Charizard/Moltres, then it was Celibi/Serperior, now its Darkrai/Magnezone. I get that these are good decks, but when four out of every five battles is the same deck it makes the game feel very repetitive. Then there's the problem of opponents quitting the match whenever you take the lead. It is very rare for me to actually complete a match that I am winning because so many players ragequit. It cheapens the victory and doesn't let me enjoy winning. my experience is mostky people spamming the same deck and rage quitting if I start to win. That is not the games fault, but it would be nice to find some way to disincentivise this behavior someway.

Title: Fix Trading
Content: I love the game and idea of it. Do not get me wrong the game is pretty fun. But for a trading card game the trading feature and concept is very very lackluster and couldâ€™ve been done better especially when that was the one thing that excited most fans. When I got the update and even saw reviews online I already knew the trading feature was going to tank. The concept is there but to be honest the fact that there is a limit to what to trade and there is a cost to to it is very disappointing. At the very least having to introduce a brand new â€œTradeâ€ currency when we have the Shinedust readily available with majorly users having thousands already is pretty much unnecessary. I suggest to take a good look at the trading system back during the PokÃ©mon XY era on the 3DS where players used to nickname Pokemon to form sentences as a way of communication so a chat box feature wouldâ€™ve been nice (obviously no bad words) and you can see what exactly what they are wanting to trade. Another way around this is basically a â€œRequest Trade featureâ€ where you can essentially let the player you are trading with know what card you want specifically. Lastly, bringing back Wonder Trade and the GTS System would be great. A Local Trade system would be nice also as it would be more efficient and easy if someone standing right in front you has the game and wants to trade. I hope you guys really consider this in the future.
Combined: Fix TradingI love the game and idea of it. Do not get me wrong the game is pretty fun. But for a trading card game the trading feature and concept is very very lackluster and couldâ€™ve been done better especially when that was the one thing that excited most fans. When I got the update and even saw reviews online I already knew the trading feature was going to tank. The concept is there but to be honest the fact that there is a limit to what to trade and there is a cost to to it is very disappointing. At the very least having to introduce a brand new â€œTradeâ€ currency when we have the Shinedust readily available with majorly users having thousands already is pretty much unnecessary. I suggest to take a good look at the trading system back during the PokÃ©mon XY era on the 3DS where players used to nickname Pokemon to form sentences as a way of communication so a chat box feature wouldâ€™ve been nice (obviously no bad words) and you can see what exactly what they are wanting to trade. Another way around this is basically a â€œRequest Trade featureâ€ where you can essentially let the player you are trading with know what card you want specifically. Lastly, bringing back Wonder Trade and the GTS System would be great. A Local Trade system would be nice also as it would be more efficient and easy if someone standing right in front you has the game and wants to trade. I hope you guys really consider this in the future.

Title: Cheaters? Hacking?
Content: The game overall is great. Pack opening is always fun and addicting. The problem is in the multiplayer. I have had many times seen people get perfect coin flips every time. To the point where none of my coin flips land on heads but every coin flip the opponent has is perfect. Itâ€™s really frustrating that people are hacking or spoofing the game. Takes the fun out of card battles. Please implement a way that allows us to report potential cheaters.

Title: Avoided Shady Mechanics Until Recently
Content:
I actually do love this app. The game itself is fun and the card collecting is implemented near perfectly in a way that makes it great even for free players who never pay a dime. 

But the recent trading mechanic they added after so much build up is BEYOND shady. The restrictions they put to prevent people from trading high value cards with each other are so ridiculous theyâ€™d be better off if they never added the trading in the first place. 

They claim to â€œhearâ€ the negative reception so Iâ€™ll update this if they act

Title: Love this game, but two critiques
Content: First off love this game itâ€™s simple does not try to be anything flashy and is exactly what it advises. However there are two issues with the game that need to be fixed. First there is no true reward for playing the random battles after completing the solo battle as you can only get 15 exp per battle won and a skip ticket if the other player thanks you. This system would be fine if there wasnâ€™t a level cap and skip ticket actually were able to be used on hour glasses more than once a month (10 individual hourglass and 40 multiple hour glasses). If youâ€™re going to have skip tickets and hour glasses at least make the shop refresh 2 weeks instead of a month. Also maybe add like a three win reward in battles that gives an hour glass as reward or the potential for one.

Title: Coin flip-to-win
Content:
The free-to-play and in-game currency are very generous. The most frustrating element is that a lot of cards use a coin flip that makes or breaks a match. 

If an achievement calls for â€œDonâ€™t lose points in a gameâ€ and have the decks include cards like Exeggutor with 80 damage for one energy, youâ€™re at the mercy of chance no matter how well you made your deck or versed you are with the OG card game. I played matches over and over and over and it takes it reduces it down to getting with coin flips just to get that achievement. As a completionist player, this is a terrible experience. 

Turn order dictates energy advantage, also a coin flip. Why canâ€™t you attach an energy on the first turn? Just donâ€™t let them attack on the first turn, similar to the OG game. 

A lot of the cards have this feature as if there are no other ways to balance the cards. This game is for casual players. No means to be competitive, just pretty to look at.
Combined:

If an achievement calls for â€œDonâ€™t lose points in a gameâ€ and have the decks include cards like Exeggutor with 80 damage for one energy, youâ€™re at the mercy of chance no matter how well you made your deck or versed you are with the OG card game. I played matches over and over and over and it takes it reduces it down to getting with coin flips just to get that achievement. As a completionist player, this is a terrible experience. 

Turn order dictates energy advantage, also a coin flip. Why canâ€™t you attach an energy on the first turn? Just donâ€™t let them attack on the first turn, similar to the OG game. 

A lot of the cards have this feature as if there are no other ways to balance the cards. This game is for casual players. No means to be competitive, just pretty to look at.

Title: Waste of Time
Content: What a shocker another big name in gaming released a yet another title with predatory mechanics and piss poor RNG. One of the most unsatisfying apps Iâ€™ve had the pleasure of downloading. 12 hours in between opening packs just to be meet with the same 5 cards I already pulled. Whatâ€™s that? You want to play against people? Let me save you the time, everyone you match against has swiped their credit card, maxed out their Momâ€™s allowance, and dipped into personal savings just so that they can play with the newest, shiniest, bestest cards. Then letâ€™s say by some miracle you donâ€™t match make with someone with a 100% PokÃ©dex, youâ€™re met with the horrid rng mechanics of a â€œcoin flipâ€ which clearly has been needed the longer the card has been in the game. So letâ€™s say you donâ€™t enjoy online play, you want to test your deck against Ai in Solo Battles. Well be prepared for the same array of onslaught from the AI in this game, whatâ€™s that? You thought just because the difficulty went up from beginner to expert that the AI would behave differently? Nope! They just repeat the same order of cards every time! They arenâ€™t even trying to hide it. Every battle with Expert level AI leads to them drawing and playing their whole assortment of PokÃ©mon and respective evolution line within the first turn, while your left there with one base level Ratatouille and 4 useless support cards. This game is really shameless and is an absolute joke to anyone who wants a polished version of a PokÃ©mon tcg.

One of the most unsatisfying apps Iâ€™ve had the pleasure of downloading. 12 hours in between opening packs just to be meet with the same 5 cards I already pulled. Whatâ€™s that? You want to play against people? Let me save you the time, everyone you match against has swiped their credit card, maxed out their Momâ€™s allowance, and dipped into personal savings just so that they can play with the newest, shiniest, bestest cards. Then letâ€™s say by some miracle you donâ€™t match make with someone with a 100% PokÃ©dex, youâ€™re met with the horrid rng mechanics of a â€œcoin flipâ€ which clearly has been needed the longer the card has been in the game. So letâ€™s say you donâ€™t enjoy online play, you want to test your deck against Ai in Solo Battles. Well be prepared for the same array of onslaught from the AI in this game, whatâ€™s that? You thought just because the difficulty went up from beginner to expert that the AI would behave differently? Nope! They just repeat the same order of cards every time! They arenâ€™t even trying to hide it. Every battle with Expert level AI leads to them drawing and playing their whole assortment of PokÃ©mon and respective evolution line within the first turn, while your left there with one base level Ratatouille and 4 useless support cards. This game is really shameless and is an absolute joke to anyone who wants a polished version of a PokÃ©mon tcg.

Title: A bit greedy
Content:
Played for a few months now and so far have found it fairly fun. I havenâ€™t spent money and when playing these sort of games I tend to not have the best of luck. You get two free 5 card packs per day, but you can earn tickets to get said packs sooner (up to a certain point per month, which could use this limit to be removed since paying players have more advantages as in more card packs and special rewards in way of unique cards and cosmetics). 

Battling is pretty fun and quick. The animations give a nice touch to the match, giving you more of a sense of satisfaction seeing some moves being played. Timers are in place forcing people to make a move or a move is made for them, usually in the form of passing on their turn, allowing you to keep going and not be stuck with someone that just wants you to concede to win the match.

The one time I reached out to the support for this app, it was slow in responding and not helpful, nor understanding. Their instructions were lacking and missing some steps, enough so I mistakingly got two free premium trials on the same account instead of one on each account. After weeks the reply was that they could not do anything in order to keep the game fair.

The trading system so far in only for paying customers. Example being that in order for me to trade any board besides a common, I have to trade 5 cards of that rarity to the game for tokens to be able to trade a sixth card to my friend. Rarer cards will give back more tokens, but you will always have to give a lot more than you get in return for tokens. Thus unless you pay for packs, you will be able to trade 1 to 4 cards with the free tokens they give at the beginning, then itâ€™s up to you to give the cards you have to be able to trade. It would have been less greedy and more friendly to free tokens play players if common cards and dust were exchangeable for tokens, example of 20 tokens per card or 20 tokens for 100 dust. But in this state it is really only intended for people that are willing to pay money.

Overall I am a happy with the new content/events that come out to keep you engaged. The gap between pay to play and free players is definitely felt a lot more in the beginning of a release, but over quite a long period of time you can earn good enough cards to be a match for the pay to play players. In essence it is a pay to win mechanic at the release of something, but over months of time you can have decks as complete/powerful as the paying players. If the paid content was purely for cosmetic items, then I would rate this game a 5, but as it stands, with the advantages the paywall provides, I can only give it a 3. I will update this review as things change in the future.

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”UPDATEâ€”â€”â€”â€”â€”
February 5 2025:

I would like to thank the development team for generous gift of trade tokens I received this morning!! That was an unexpected nice surprise! 

I have kept playing everyday and am enjoying the new live events. The addition of an EX available as a promo prize card is exciting and has a potential of helping towards making the new trade feature more usable for free to play players. If the rate at which EX and rarer cards is highly increased, then it definitely would be another way of tackling the trade token conversion rate problem. 
I have a slight concern in approaching the problem this way, where the overall value of the EX cards would go down due to the increased ease in getting them. Maybe a way to avoid that could be in having a non stop single player event that rewards EX level rarity cards to use specifically for exchanging for trade tokens. 
That could be an innovative way of solving the problem instead of adding trade in token value to common cards and changing the token exchange rates. Not knowing the difficulty in programming these changes in the game, I do not know which would be the cleaner way for the development team to approach this. What I do know is that a change is desperately needed to make this trade feature more realistically available for free to play players. This is not discounting that it is still not easy nor cheap for paying players! At the end of the day though this feature if easier to use for paying players due to the increased amount of cards they receive, thus creating a bigger imbalance between paying and free to play players.
If the bigger difference between paying and free play players is purposely introduced, I would suggest adding battle lobbies for just free to play players, making it more enjoyable for that community having more balanced deck opponents in relation to how many cards can be collected for free play players.

I hope the different suggestions I gave above will be seen and considered to bring back more balance between paying and free play players. Since the update I have used the trade feature to trade common cards with my friends. I havenâ€™t traded anything requiring tokens in the hopes that someday there will be changes that will allow trading rarer cards cheaper than what is realistically only fairly doable with the tokens given for free as gifts from the developer team.

I will update the review and try to keep it shorter as things change.

Title: Middle of the road
Content: Other than spending ridiculous amounts of money, there isnâ€™t really a way to collect everything in the packs, due to the massive variety of rarities, and the pull rates. The anxiously awaited â€œtradeâ€ feature is not trading. Basically, you throw a card at another player (whose collection you canâ€™t see) and hope they throw something you want back at you. It also is severely limited in how many times you can do it, and requires yet another resource to initiate. Again: you have no idea what you are getting back (or if you will get anything, since the â€œpartnerâ€ can reject the trade outright). You would be better off just buying paper cards. Iâ€™ve enjoyed just opening the half packs and collecting. If you want something to spend 5-10 minutes a day on, sure. Just donâ€™t make the mistake of spending money.

Title: Fantastic game- Horrible trading feature?
Content: This is really a one of a kind card game, made wonderfully accessible and seamless for mobile. It had me hooked the same day I got it. However- after months of waiting for the trading feature to be implemented, it seems to be completely unusable. This wasnâ€™t a mistake, because itâ€™s clear the developers made the trading system purposefully prohibitive to use in order to drive up sales on card packs, forcing you to invest large amounts simply to make trading viable. As it is, itâ€™s egregiously anti-consumer, and thereâ€™s no reason to use it at all. You can get the game, you can even enjoy it, just donâ€™t give them a single cent until they fix this.

Title: No content, bad trading, pay to win
Content:
So I first started playing a little bit ago as a free to play player, but let me tell you right off the bat you wonâ€™t have much fun battling online if you donâ€™t spend money and have 4 EX cards in your deck. The drop rate for â€œgoodâ€ cards seems super low and there is no pity system to guarantee a good card after X amount of pulls, the pack opening system just feels really bad and unrewarding. Itâ€™s even worse after you spend all your hourglasses, booster pack open refresh energy, and still pull nothing but basic cards. No content really expect for opening packs, playing against people online who have spent thousands to get cards you wish you had and then they stomp you turn two, or events that are just â€œplay online matches or against aiâ€ boring! The trading is so bad in this game wow, for a TRADING CARD GAME it should be leagues above what it is, destroy your good cards you waited days or weeks to get to get a third of the amount of currency you need to trade a lower tier card than the one you just destroyed? What a horrible system, also you need to be friends with people to trade and there is no way to chat in app to set up a trade. Again game is very pay to win as I see it, you either fork over your wallet to have fun and MAYBE get some cool and useful cards, again no pity system so you could just end up with nothing, or just wait and open your two free packs a day and still get nothing, thus incentivizing you to spend. Also if you do pull a cool EX card you better hope you have the basic pre evolution Pokemon card, or cards, or you literally just donâ€™t get to use that super rare cool awesome mega card you just got, feels so bad and what a slap in the face to the player. The game just feels greedy and lackluster for what it is, feels rushed and half baked. The UI is also so bad and filled with so many extra clicks to get to what you really want. Give it a shot if you want but donâ€™t expect to really be able to build decks and play the game the â€œright wayâ€ until you four or five months in, or just pay money which is what they want, and have some decent cards to play withâ€¦ 
GREEDY DEVELOPERS!!

Title: Needs Improvement
Content:
I felt pretty excited when this game first came out. Itâ€™s nice to be able to see the nice effects from holos and EX cards. I wish that it didnâ€™t cost so much to open packs of cards. With how many sets there are and the lack of currency you get for opening packs, I have yet to complete a single set. I think itâ€™s a great game to check into when waking up and before going to bed. Thatâ€™s about it.

The battle system is terrible. It takes 3 points for a win. If you knock out an EX card, you gain 2 points. If you knock out a regular card, youâ€™ll be rewarded with 1 point. Most of the time, someone happens to pull an EX as their first card. It pretty much decides the game. Thereâ€™s no time to try to compete. Itâ€™s even worse when the opponent has a Pokemon card that allows them to gain energy and place the energy onto whichever Pokemon. It makes it way too easy for the person to win since they get an infinite supply of energy and you donâ€™t have a strong enough card, nor an energy generating card. I think they should require 6 points for the win to allow people time to try to make a comeback or be on an even playing field. 

I probably would only recommend this game to a child. Sure, itâ€™ll be something they quickly become bored of but at least theyâ€™ll be in awe for a few minutes each time they open a pack of cards.

Title: Trading disaster
Content: Most of the game is fun, but the actual trading mechanic is a pay to win mess. If you want to trade a rare card to your friend, you have to destroy 4 of the same rarity of card and then trade them a 5th one. I understand preventing people from cheating with multiple accounts but this completely locks out players from trading unless they want to trade a Rattata for a Pidgey.
Combined: Trading disasterMost of the game is fun, but the actual trading mechanic is a pay to win mess. If you want to trade a rare card to your friend, you have to destroy 4 of the same rarity of card and then trade them a 5th one. I understand preventing people from cheating with multiple accounts but this completely locks out players from trading unless they want to trade a Rattata for a Pidgey.

Title: A Monetized Dumpster Fire
Content:
PokÃ©mon TCG Pocket Review: A Monetized Dumpster Fire

Letâ€™s get one thing straight: Pokemon TCG Pocket is an Abomasnowâ€™nation to both Pokemon fans and trading card game enthusiasts. What could have been an exciting, mobile friendly way to enjoy the Pokemon TCG is instead a soulless, money grabbing mess that strips away everything fun about collecting and battling.

Gacha Mechanics â€œMasquerainâ€™ingâ€ as a Card Game

Get it? Get it?! Any whoâ€¦this game isnâ€™t about strategy or deck building. Itâ€™s about daily pack openings with an aggressive monetization model. You donâ€™t â€œcollectâ€ cards in a meaningful way. You pray to the random number generator gods and hope to Arceus you pull something decent. The odds canâ€™t be that bad though,  right? Right? Well, you tell me. 0.050% chance you open a rare pack. You read that right. To add insult to injury-thereâ€™s no system to exchange duplicate cards for in-game currency, meaning the useless extra copies youâ€™ll pull 99.950% of the time just sit there, mocking you. Meanwhile, in-game currency can be used to unlock cards, but thereâ€™s no direct way to work toward the ones you actually want. Itâ€™s an artificial, exploitative system designed to keep you chasing the next pack instead of building a deck you actually enjoy.

A Trading System Thatâ€™s a Total Muk-up

The recent addition of a trading feature should have been a saving grace, but itâ€™s somehow even worse than expected. Also, donâ€™t skip past the fact that I stated trading is a recent addition. I hope they released the game as Pokemon CG at first! Anyway, instead of a simple, straightforward way to exchange cards with friends, we get a convoluted mess of â€œTrade Staminaâ€ and â€œTrade Tokensâ€ because God forbid we just trade cards like a normal human. It feels like the developers actively sat down and asked, How can we make this as tedious and anti consumer as possible? Seems they forgot what the T in TCG stands for. 

Watered-Down Gameplay That Insults TCG Fans

If you were hoping for deep, strategic gameplay like the physical Pokemon TCG or even Pokemon TCG Live, youâ€™re in for a disappointment. Battles feel shallow, uninspired, and largely automated. Thereâ€™s no real room for skill. It just another case of â€œtap the screen and hope you win.â€ The fact that Yu-Gi-Oh! Master Duel can faithfully recreate its complex card game while Pokemon delivers something that feels designed for a Slowpoke. Itâ€™s beyond embarrassing.

And itâ€™s not just about depth. The matchmaking is a complete joke. You will be matched regularly with level 30+ players before you ever see level 10 all while under the Beginner tab. Thereâ€™s no balance, no proper ranking system and a whole lot of Unown. Pure chaos. Worse yet, losing a match nets zero rewards. No points, no progressâ€”just wasted time.

Repetitive Meta That Kills Any Variety

Even if you suffer through the awful matchmaking and dumbed-down gameplay, youâ€™ll quickly notice that every match feels exactly the same. The same overpowered cards dominate the meta, making deck variety non-existent. If youâ€™re not running those cards, youâ€™re at an instant disadvantage. Combine that with the ridiculous card acquisition system, and itâ€™s clear the game is designed to keep you grinding endlessly or spending money just to remain competitive.

Final Verdict: Stay Far Away

Pokemon TCG Pocket is everything wrong with modern mobile gamingâ€”paywalled progression, shallow mechanics, and a deliberately broken economy that treats players like cash cows. If youâ€™re looking for a way to enjoy the Pokemon TCG, do yourself a favor and play literally anything else. 

Score: 0/10 â€“ A Masterclass in How to Ruin a Beloved Franchise

(Side note** How silly of me, Pokemon isnâ€™t doing this as a cash grab! They added daily spending limits of around $140 or about $4200 a month to save you from yourself. Because 2 house mortgages a month on virtual cards isnâ€™t too much! What clowns ğŸ¤¡) also note, when you spend that $4200 a month to build the Meta deck of youâ€™re dreams, PokÃ©mon is within their rights to ban any card(s) straight into the sun, never to be used again, as they see fit to maintain a â€œfair battle environmentâ€.

Letâ€™s get one thing straight: Pokemon TCG Pocket is an Abomasnowâ€™nation to both Pokemon fans and trading card game enthusiasts. What could have been an exciting, mobile friendly way to enjoy the Pokemon TCG is instead a soulless, money grabbing mess that strips away everything fun about collecting and battling.

Gacha Mechanics â€œMasquerainâ€™ingâ€ as a Card Game

Get it? Get it?! Any whoâ€¦this game isnâ€™t about strategy or deck building. Itâ€™s about daily pack openings with an aggressive monetization model. You donâ€™t â€œcollectâ€ cards in a meaningful way. You pray to the random number generator gods and hope to Arceus you pull something decent. The odds canâ€™t be that bad though,  right? Right? Well, you tell me. 0.050% chance you open a rare pack. You read that right. To add insult to injury-thereâ€™s no system to exchange duplicate cards for in-game currency, meaning the useless extra copies youâ€™ll pull 99.950% of the time just sit there, mocking you. Meanwhile, in-game currency can be used to unlock cards, but thereâ€™s no direct way to work toward the ones you actually want. Itâ€™s an artificial, exploitative system designed to keep you chasing the next pack instead of building a deck you actually enjoy.

A Trading System Thatâ€™s a Total Muk-up

The recent addition of a trading feature should have been a saving grace, but itâ€™s somehow even worse than expected. Also, donâ€™t skip past the fact that I stated trading is a recent addition. I hope they released the game as Pokemon CG at first! Anyway, instead of a simple, straightforward way to exchange cards with friends, we get a convoluted mess of â€œTrade Staminaâ€ and â€œTrade Tokensâ€ because God forbid we just trade cards like a normal human. It feels like the developers actively sat down and asked, How can we make this as tedious and anti consumer as possible? Seems they forgot what the T in TCG stands for. 

Watered-Down Gameplay That Insults TCG Fans

If you were hoping for deep, strategic gameplay like the physical Pokemon TCG or even Pokemon TCG Live, youâ€™re in for a disappointment. Battles feel shallow, uninspired, and largely automated. Thereâ€™s no real room for skill. It just another case of â€œtap the screen and hope you win.â€ The fact that Yu-Gi-Oh! Master Duel can faithfully recreate its complex card game while Pokemon delivers something that feels designed for a Slowpoke. Itâ€™s beyond embarrassing.

And itâ€™s not just about depth. The matchmaking is a complete joke. You will be matched regularly with level 30+ players before you ever see level 10 all while under the Beginner tab. Thereâ€™s no balance, no proper ranking system and a whole lot of Unown. Pure chaos. Worse yet, losing a match nets zero rewards. No points, no progressâ€”just wasted time.

Repetitive Meta That Kills Any Variety

Even if you suffer through the awful matchmaking and dumbed-down gameplay, youâ€™ll quickly notice that every match feels exactly the same. The same overpowered cards dominate the meta, making deck variety non-existent. If youâ€™re not running those cards, youâ€™re at an instant disadvantage. Combine that with the ridiculous card acquisition system, and itâ€™s clear the game is designed to keep you grinding endlessly or spending money just to remain competitive.

Final Verdict: Stay Far Away

Pokemon TCG Pocket is everything wrong with modern mobile gamingâ€”paywalled progression, shallow mechanics, and a deliberately broken economy that treats players like cash cows. If youâ€™re looking for a way to enjoy the Pokemon TCG, do yourself a favor and play literally anything else. 

Score: 0/10 â€“ A Masterclass in How to Ruin a Beloved Franchise

(Side note** How silly of me, Pokemon isnâ€™t doing this as a cash grab! They added daily spending limits of around $140 or about $4200 a month to save you from yourself. Because 2 house mortgages a month on virtual cards isnâ€™t too much! What clowns ğŸ¤¡) also note, when you spend that $4200 a month to build the Meta deck of youâ€™re dreams, PokÃ©mon is within their rights to ban any card(s) straight into the sun, never to be used again, as they see fit to maintain a â€œfair battle environmentâ€.
